sn12.32:1.2: Then the mendicant Kalara the Aristocrat went up to Venerable Sariputta and exchanged greetings with him.
sn12.32:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him,
sn12.32:1.4: “Reverend Sariputta, the mendicant Phagguna of the Top-Knot has resigned the training and returned to a lesser life.”
sn12.32:1.5: “That venerable mustn’t have gained any solace in this teaching and training.”
sn12.32:2.1: “Well then, has Venerable Sariputta found found in this teaching and training?”
sn12.32:5.1: Then Kalara the Aristocrat went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn12.32:5.3: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’”
sn12.32:6.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
sn12.32:6.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell Sariputta that
sn12.32:6.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Sariputta and said to him,
sn12.32:6.6: “Yes, reverend,” replied Sariputta. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
sn12.32:6.7: “Sariputta, is it really true that you have declared enlightenment:
sn12.32:6.8: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place”’?”
sn12.32:6.9: “Sir, I did not state the matter in these words and phrases.”
sn12.32:6.10: “Sariputta, no matter how a gentleman declares enlightenment, what he has declared should be regarded as such.”
sn12.32:6.11: “Sir, did I not also say that
sn12.32:6.12: I did not state the matter in these words and phrases?”
sn12.32:7.1: “Sariputta, suppose they were to ask you:
sn12.32:7.2: ‘But Reverend Sariputta, how have you known and seen so that you’ve declared enlightenment:
sn12.32:7.3: “I understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”’
sn12.32:8.1: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
sn12.32:8.5: ‘Reverends, when the source of rebirth ended, I knew “it is ended”.
sn12.32:8.7: I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’
sn12.32:8.8: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”
sn12.32:9.1: “But Sariputta, suppose they were to ask you:
sn12.32:9.2: ‘But what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of rebirth?’
sn12.32:9.4: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
sn12.32:9.7: ‘Continued existence is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of rebirth.’
sn12.32:9.8: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”
sn12.32:10.1: “But Sariputta, suppose they were to ask you:
sn12.32:10.2: ‘What is the source of continued existence?’
sn12.32:10.4: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
sn12.32:10.7: ‘Grasping is the source of continued existence.’
sn12.32:10.8: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”
sn12.32:11.1: “But Sariputta, suppose they were to ask you:
sn12.32:11.3: But Sariputta, suppose they were to ask you:
sn12.32:11.6: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
sn12.32:11.10: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”
sn12.32:12.1: “But Sariputta, suppose they were to ask you:
sn12.32:12.2: ‘But how have you known and seen so that the relishing of feelings is no longer present?’
sn12.32:12.4: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
sn12.32:12.11: When I understood this, the relishing of feelings was no longer present.’
sn12.32:12.12: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”
sn12.32:13.2: The same point may also be briefly explained in this way:
sn12.32:14.1: But Sariputta, suppose they were to ask you:
sn12.32:14.2: ‘But Reverend, how have you been released that you declare enlightenment:
sn12.32:14.3: “I understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”?’
sn12.32:14.5: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
sn12.32:14.9: ‘Because of an inner release with the ending of all grasping, I live mindfully so that defilements don’t defile me and I don’t look down on myself.’
sn12.32:14.10: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”
sn12.32:15.2: The same point may also be briefly explained in this way:
sn12.32:15.3: ‘I have no uncertainty regarding the defilements spoken of by the ascetic. I have no doubt that I’ve given them up.’”
sn12.32:15.4: That is what the Buddha said.
sn12.32:15.5: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
sn12.32:16.1: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sariputta said to the mendicants,
sn12.32:16.2: “Reverends, the Buddha asked me the first question without letting me know beforehand, so I hesitated.
sn12.32:16.3: But when the Buddha agreed with my answer, I thought:
sn12.32:16.4: ‘If the Buddha were to question me all day on this matter in different words and ways, I could answer all day with different words and ways.
sn12.32:16.5: If he were to question me all night,
sn12.32:16.17: or seven days and nights, I could answer in different words and ways for seven days and nights.’”
sn12.32:17.1: Then Kalara the Aristocrat went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn12.32:17.2: “Sir, Venerable Sariputta has roared his lion’s roar!”
sn12.32:17.3: (And he told the Buddha all that Sariputta had said.)
sn12.32:18.1: “Mendicant, Sariputta has clearly penetrated the principle of the teachings, so that he could answer any questions I might ask him in different words and ways up to the seventh day and night.”
